item.title: Search trends of Covid-19
item.description: This is a post in progress! Importing the data For this, I will use the R package “gtrendsR” for the first time. library("dplyr") library("readr") library("gtrendsR") library("googlesheets4") covid_data %>% filter(provincial_case_id==100) %>% select(province, date_report) ## # A tibble: 4 x 2 ## province date_report ## <chr> <chr> ## 1 Ontario 14-03-2020 ## 2 BC 16-03-2020 ## 3 Alberta 18-03-2020 ## 4 Quebec 19-03-2020 So Ontario had its 100th case on March 14th, BC on March 16th, Alberta on March 18th and Quebec on March 19th.

item.title: Ottawa Winters -2019
item.description: The setting It was a cold and snowy beginning to Spring here in Ottawa. We had just had one of the most intense and drawn out winters, or at least that is what it felt like to me. To confirm my suspicians, I wanted to take a look back at previous years to see how this past winter ranked. Luckily for me, there is an excellent publically available data source for historical Canadian weather data, provided by Environment Canada.
